required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Resistance and/or Endurance Training, What is Most Effective in Prevention of Cardiovascular Diseases?
clinical_study.official_title: Strength Training Versus Aerobic Interval Training to Modify Risk Factors of the Metabolic Syndrome

lead_sponsor.agency: Norwegian University of Science and Technology

clinical_study.source: Norwegian University of Science and Technology

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of the present study was to evaluate the effects of aerobic interval training versus strength training or a combination of these regimes on factors comprising the metabolic syndrome in order to find the most effective exercise regime for patients with metabolic syndrome.

detailed_description.textblock:
In the Western world, approximately 25% of young to middle-aged adults have metabolic syndrome. There seem to be a strong age-dependence in the prevalence of the metabolic syndrome, but the incidence rises rapidly within adolescents and middle-aged groups and follows the development of obesity in the general population. Metabolic syndrome confers an increased risk of coronary heart disease, cardiovascular disease, and premature death; therefore, effective and affordable strategies to combat the syndrome would be of great individual and social importance.
Despite the general agreement that moderate-intensity physical activity for a minimum of 30 min five days per week or vigorous-intensity aerobic physical activity for a minimum of 20 min three days a week promote and maintain health, the optimal training regime to treat metabolic syndrome and its associated cardiovascular abnormalities remains uncertain.

intervention.description: carried out 3 times per week for 12 weeks
carried out 3 times per week for 12 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Having metabolic syndrome according to international diabetes foundations definition (IDF).
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unstable angina pectoris
- Uncompensated heart failure
- Myocardial infarction during the past 4 weeks
- Complex ventricular arrhythmias
- Kidney failure

overall_official.affiliation: Norwegian University of Science and Technology

results_reference.citation: Stensvold D, Slørdahl SA, Wisløff U. Effect of exercise training on inflammation status among people with metabolic syndrome. Metab Syndr Relat Disord. 2012 Aug;10(4):267-72. doi: 10.1089/met.2011.0140. Epub 2012 Mar 28.
